list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f$ and $g$ be functions such that $g(x)=3f(x−2)+1$, for
$x∈R$.
The graph of $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ after the following
transformations:
$$$​a vertical stretch by a factor of k, followed bya horizontal translation of a units, followed bya vertical translation of b units.​$$$

Write down the value of:


$k$;


$a$;


$b$. [3]





Let $h(x)=−2g(x)$, for $x∈R$.
The point P$(3,4)$ on the graph of $g$ is mapped to point Q on the graph
of $h$.

Find the coordinates of Q. [3]
list.markScheme:
$k=3​$


$a=2​$


$b=1​$




The graph of $h$ is obtained from the graph of $g$ using two
transformations.
Their geometric descriptions are:
$$$transformation 1:transformation 2:​vertical stretch by a factor of 2;reflection in the x-axis.​$$$
If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/81adf7f8-647c-479f-bd0f-8f896cd0c7c3/images/fe8c659b-613c-4fc0-a165-b07d10509323/1510a052325892668888784527ddbb81323a45d9.svg)


Hence the coordinates of Q are
$(3,−8)​$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of $y=f(x)$, for
$−1≤x≤2$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/ee08b3c6-49a0-41f7-814f-bb4d9079b11c/ccc9d5942ccfefc2e6313a34922fed1ada13594f.svg)




Write down the value of:


$f(1)$;


$f−1(−2)$. [2]





Find $(f∘f)(1)$. [2]



Sketch the graph of $y=f(−x)$ on the same grid above. [2]
list.markScheme:
$f(1)=2​$


$f−1(−2)=−1​$




We have
$$$(f∘f)(1)​=f(f(1))=f(2)=6​​$$$


The graph of $y=f(−x)$ is a reflection of the graph of $y=f(x)$
in the $y$-axis.
Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y=f(−x)$ on the same grid below,
we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8407806b-3c8d-4f8a-ba57-52619272880d/images/64f14811-163b-49f4-8bcc-e95f5b9a1d96/d2b3518aa3484d1ffd19b0a1dd3f20d6f92c6046.svg)

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $f(x)=x3$ and $g(x)=5(x−2)3$, for $x∈R$.
The graph of $g$ can be obtained from the graph of $f$ using two transformations.


Give a full geometric description of each of the transformations. [2]



The graph of $g$ is translated by 4 units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis, and 1 unit in the direction of the negative $y$-axis to give the graph of a
function $h$.
The point P$(1,1)$ on the graph of $f$ is translated to point Q on the
graph of $h$.

Find the coordinates of Q. [4]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$transformation 1:transformation 2:​vertical stretch by a factor of 5​translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive x-axis.​​$$$


If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ from part (a), and transformation $3$ from part (b) to P, we find


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1a61284-0cae-4301-9a9e-89a7e58d9d56/images/b28c508c-6131-4aee-a6fd-a87b131e9f21/577066d1f46b6880207621796d732b7e8ac43d46.svg)


Hence the coordinates of Q are
$(7,4)​$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(x)=0.2ex+2−4$, for $−3≤x≤2$.


On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$. [3]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)




Find the coordinates of:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept. [2]





The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$.

Find $g(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph of $y=f(x)$ for $−3≤x≤2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)






Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$0.2ex+2−4x​=0≈0.996[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$(0.996,0)​$


Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$y​=f(0)=0.2e0+2−4≈−2.52​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$(0,−2.52)​$




We have
$$$g(x)​=−f(x−1)+2=−[0.2e(x−1)+2−4]+2=−0.2ex+1+6​​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Let $f(t)=3t2+27$, where $t>0$.
The graph of a function $g$ is obtained when the graph of $f$ is
transformed by
$$$​a stretch by a scale of 91​ parallel to the y-axis, followed bya horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5​$$$


Find $g(t)$, giving your answer in the form $a(t−b)2+c$.
[4]



A particle moves along a straight line so that its velocity in
m s$−1$, at time $t$ seconds, is given by
$g(t)$.

Find the distance the particle travels between $t=7$ and
$t=10$. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$g(t)​=91​f(t−4)−5=91​[3(t−4)2+27]−5=31​(t−4)2−2​​$$$


The distance the particle travels between $t=7$ and $t=10$ is
$$$distance​=∫710​∣g(t)∣dt=∫710​​31​(t−4)2−2​dt=15 m​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=2cos(x−2π​)+3$ and $g(x)=4cos(x+2π​)+2$.
The function $f$ is mapped onto $g$
by three transformations.

Fully describe each of the transformations and the order in which they must be applied. [3]


A new function is such that $h(x)=g(x)+k$ where $k∈R$.

Find the minimum value of $k$ such that $h(x)≥0$ for all $x$. [2]
list.markScheme:
By considering the differences between the functions we can work out the transformations needed to map $f(x)$ to $g(x)$.
First we notice that the inner functions are different.
$$$f(x)=2cos(x−2π​)+3g(x)=4cos(x+2π​)+2​$$$
If we add $π$ units to the inner function of $f(x)$, it will equal the inner function of  $g(x)$.
$$$​A1​$$$
Hence
$$$f(x+π)f(x+π)​=2cos(x−2π​+π)+3=2cos(x+2π​)+3​$$$
Comparing the function $f(x+π)$ to $g(x)$, we notice that the coefficient of cosine has been doubled.
$$$f(x+π)=2cos(x+2π​)+3g(x)=4cos(x+2π​)+2​$$$
Hence, if we multiply $f(x+π)$ by $2$ we would have
$$$​A1​$$$
$$$2f(x+π)=2(2cos(x+2π​)+3)2f(x+π)=4cos(x+2π​)+6​$$$
If we continue comparing the function $2f(x+π)$ to $g(x)$, we see there is a difference of $4$ units.
$$$2f(x+π)g(x)​=4cos(x+2π​)+6=4cos(x+2π​)+2​$$$
Hence, if we apply a vertical shift of $−4$ to $2f(x+π)$, we will obtain $g(x)$.
$$$​A1​$$$
$$$2f(x+π)−4​=4cos(x+2π​)+6−4=4cos(x+2π​)+2=g(x)​$$$
Summarising the $3$ transformations, there is
a horizontal shift $left$ of $π$ units, followed by a vertical stretch by a scale factor of $2$ , followed by a vertical shift of $−4$ units.
Note: The horizontal shift could also come after the vertical transformations, however the two vertical transformations must be applied in the order given.


In order to apply a vertical translation such that $g(x)>0$ for all $x$, we need to know the minimum value of $g(x)$.
The minimum value of cosine is $−1$. Hence we can determine the minimum of $g(x)$
$$$​(M1)​$$$
$$$g(x)​=4cos(x+2π​)+2=4(−1)+2=−2​$$$
Hence, we need to translate the graph vertically upwards at least $2$ units.
Therefore, the minimum value is $k=2​$.
$$$​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Consider the functions $f(x)=3cos(x)+29​$ and $g(x)=3cos(x+3π​)+A$, where $x∈R$ and $A<29​$.

Describe a sequence of two transformations that transforms the graph of $f$ to the graph of $g$. [3]


The $y$-intercept of the graph $g$ is at the point $(0,29​)$

Find the range of $g$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Applying a translation of $a$ units in the direction of the negative $x$-axis to a function $f$ is shown as $f(x+a)$, and a translation of $b$ units in the direction of the negative $y$-axis is shown as $f(x)−b$.
Therefore a translation of $3π​$ units in the direction of the negative $x$-axis would be $f(x+3π​)$. We have
$$$f(x+3π​)​=3cos(x+3π​)+29​​$$$
Given that $A<29​$, if we then apply a translation of $29​−A$ units in the direction of the negative $y$-axis, we get
$$$f(x+3π​)−(29​−A)​=3cos(x+3π​)+29​−(29​−A)=3cos(x+3π​)+A=g(x)​$$$
Therefore we have the following transformations in any order
$$$T1​T2​​:translation of 3π​ units in the direction of the negative x-axis​:translation of 29​−A units in the direction of the negative y-axis​​$$$


We have $g(0)=29​$. Solving for $A$, we get
$$$3cos(0+3π​)+A3(21​)+AA​=29​=29​=3​$$$
Therefore $g(x)=3cos(x+3π​)+3$ , and the following inequalities hold:
$$$−1≤cos(x+3π​)−3≤3cos(x+3π​)0≤3cos(x+3π​)+30≤g(x)​≤1≤3≤6≤6​$$$
Therefore the range of $g$ is $0≤g(x)≤6​$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
[Maximum marks: 10]
The function $f(x)=asin(bx)+c$ where $0≤x≤π$ and $a,b,c∈R$ is shown below.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/0547420d-b08d-4f9e-bd37-d903d3be790b/AA1154.JPEG)


The coordinates of the first two stationary points are $(6π​,−1)$ and $(2π​,3)$ respectively.

Find


a.


c.


b. [5]





The domain of $f(x)$ is restricted to $2π​≤x≤k$, where $k∈R$. This restriction allows an inverse to exist.

Find the largest possible value of $k$. [2]


Another function is defined as $g(x)=−2f(21​x)+3$.

Determine the coordinates of the first maximum value of $g(x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
To find the value of $a$, which is known as the amplitude, we must find half of the vertical distance between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/a928181a-4fcd-4ea9-b71e-dc8f5cea02c9/AA1154a.JPEG)


We can see from the diagram that the curve is a reflection of $sinx$ in the $x−$axis, therefore the value of $a$ must be negative.
$$$hack​A1​$$$
Therefore
$$$a​=−23−(−1)​=−2​​R1​$$$


To find the  value of $c$ we must find the $y−$value half way between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/f6143e17-9146-4ce4-9c33-b01bced64c56/AA1154b.JPEG)


Therefore
$$$c​=23+(−1)​=1​​A1​$$$


To find $b$ we use the formula $T=b2π​$.
We can use the diagram to find $T$ and see that $2T​$ is the $x−$distance between the maximum and minimum values.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/c7dc5b6a-813a-4ffb-bafd-b8fb49ff2f45/AA1154c%20(1).JPEG)


Hence
$$$2T​TT​=(2π​−6π​)=2(2π​−6π​)=32π​​A1​$$$
Using this value of $T$ and the formula stated above we can find $b$.
$$$32π​b​=b2π​=3​​A1​$$$




For an inverse to exist the function must be one-to-one, this means it must pass the horizontal line test. We can see this is satisfied by the red part of $f(x)$  shown below
$$$hack​M1​$$$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/697d6ed2-4137-494f-ada6-07cd489eefc7/images/2b4f5cbc-7374-4bd7-a0b3-ee6657792bc7/AA1154inv.JPEG)


We can see that if we add one complete time period to $6π​$ we will get $k$, hence
$$$k​=6π​+32π​=65π​​​A1​$$$


First we split the vertical and horizontal transformations.
The inner function of $f$ is the horizontal transformations and everything else is vertical.
$$$​−2f(21​x)+3Vertical×−2+3​​Horizontal÷2​$$$
Lets do the vertical transformations first. We don't need to transform the entire function. It is easier to identify a single point and transform that.
Notice that we are multiplying by a negative number, that means $g$ will be a vertical reflection of $f$.
Therefore the first maximum point of $g$ will be the image of the transformation of the first minimum point of $f$.
$$$hack​M1​$$$
Therefore we need to apply our transformations to the point $(6π​,−1)$.
We transform the $y$-coordinate by $×−2$ and then $+3$, therefore the transformed $y$-coordinate is $−1×−2+3=5$.
We transform the $x$-coordinate by $×1/21​$.therefore the transformed $x$-coordinate is $6π​×2=3π​$.
Therefore $the first maximum of g(x) has coordinates (3π​,5).​$
$$$hack​A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $f(x)=3x2+12x+9$, for $x∈R$.

For the graph of $f$, find:


the $y$-intercept;


the $x$-intercepts. [4]





The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x)=a(x−h)2+k$.


Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]



For the graph of $f$, write down:


the coordinates of the vertex;


the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]





The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 4 units in the direction of the positive $y$ axis.

Find $g(x)$, giving your answer in the form
$g(x)=px2+qx+r$.[4]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(x)=3x2+12x+9$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$f(0)​=3(0)2+12(0)+9=9​$$$
Hence the $y$-intercept is
$A(0,9)​$


Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$3x2+12x+9x2+4x+3(x+3)(x+1)x​=0=0=0=−3,−1​$$$
Hence the
$x$-intercepts are
$B(−3,0)​$
and
$C(−1,0)​$




Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$$f(x)​=3x2+12x+9=3[x2+4x]+9=3[(x+2)2−4]+9=3(x+2)2−3​$$$
Hence we find
$a=3,h=−2​$
and  $k=−3​$




$(−2,−3)​$


$x=−2​$




We have
$$$g(x)​=−f(x)+4=−(3x2+12x+9)+4=−3x2−12x−5​​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Let $f(x)=2x2+4x+p$, for $x∈R$, where
$p∈Z$.


The equation $f(x)=0$ has two equal roots.


Write down the value of the discriminant of $f$.


Show that $p=2$. [3]





For the graph of $f$, find:


the equation of the axis of symmetry.


the coordinates of the vertex; [4]





Write down the solution to the equation $f(x)=0$. [1]



The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x)=a(x−h)2+k$.
Find
the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection
in the $x$-axis. Find the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of
$g$. [2]
list.markScheme:
$△=0​$


We have
$$$△0016​=b2−4ac=42−4(2)(p)=16−8p=8p​$$$
$$$p=2​$$$






Using the axis of symmetry formula, we get
$$$xx​=−2ab​=−2(2)4​​$$$
$$$x=−1​$$$


Evaluating $f(x)=2x2+4x+2$ for $x=−1$, we have
$$$f(−1)​=2(−1)2+4(−1)+2=0​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$(−1,0)​$




$x=−1​$


Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$$f(x)​=2x2+4x+2=2[x2+2x]+2=2[(x+1)2−1]+2=2(x+1)2​$$$
Hence we find
$a=2,h=−1​$
and  $k=0​$


We have
$$$g(x)​=−f(x)=−2(x+1)2​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex of
the graph of $g$ are
$(−1,0)​$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Let $f(x)=2(x−1)2−8$, for $x∈R$.


Show that $f(x)=2x2−4x−6$. [2]



For the graph of $f$:


write down the coordinates of the vertex;


write down the $y$-intercept;


find both $x$-intercepts. [7]





Hence sketch the graph of $f$. [3]



Let $g(x)=6x2$, for $x∈R$.
The graph of $f$ may be obtained from the graph of $g$ using the
following three transformations:
$$$​∙ a compression of scale factor a in the y-direction, followed by∙ a horizontal translation of h units, followed by∙ a vertical translation of k units.​$$$

Find the values of $a,h$ and $k$. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$f(x)​=2(x−1)2−8=2(x2−2x+1)−8=2x2−4x−6​​$$$




$(1,−8)​$


$P(0,−6)​$


Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$2x2−4x−6x2−2x−3(x+1)(x−3)x​=0=0=0=−1,3​$$$
Hence the $x$-intercepts
are
$A(−1,0)​$
and
$B(3,0)​$




If we sketch the graph of $f$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/defd40b3-8635-4c03-88d0-1ea05c7ccca1/images/42674bdd-229f-43b4-bb47-2584f965f100/8374016b8a888aa9fc9466667cfab6ca4babdde2.svg)




We have
$$$f(x)2(x−1)2−82(x−1)2−8​=ag(x−h)+k=a[6(x−h)2]+k=6a(x−h)2+k​$$$
Hence we
find
$a=1/3,h=1​$
and  $k=−8​$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $f(x)=2x2−8x+6$, for $x∈R$.


Write down the value of $f(0)$. [1]



Solve the equation $f(x)=0$. [3]



The function $f$ can be written in the form $f(x)=a(x−h)2+k$.


Find the values of $a$, $h$ and $k$. [5]



For the graph of $f$, write down:


the coordinates of the vertex;


the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]





The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a reflection in the $x$-axis, followed by a translation of 1 unit to the right and 3 units up.

Find $g(x)$, giving your answer in the form
$g(x)=px2+qx+r$. [4]

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x)=a(x+1)(x+5)$, for $x∈R$, where
$a∈Z$. The following diagram shows part of the graph of
$f$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5a0794f4-b904-4254-9ade-c72ff4d130c0/c560b93b90031104353dd8752d2c6976f60f1751.svg)


The graph of $f$ has $x$-intercepts at $(p,0)$ and $(q,0)$, and a
$y$-intercept at $(0,−10)$.




Write down the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.


Find the value of $a$. [6]





Find the equation of the axis of symmetry. [2]



Find the coordinates of the vertex. [3]



The graph of a function $g$ is obtained from the graph of $f$ by a
reflection in the $y$-axis, followed by a translation of 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis. The point P$(−2,6)$ on the graph of $f$ is mapped to point Q on the graph of
$g$.

Find the coordinates of Q. [4]
list.markScheme:
$p=−5​$  and
$q=−1​$


Using the coordinates of the $y$-intercept, we find
$$$f(0)a(0+1)(0+5)5a​=−10=−10=−10​$$$
$$$a=−2​$$$




We have
$$$f(x)​=−2(x+1)(x+5)=−2(x2+6x+5)=−2x2−12x−10​$$$
Hence, using the axis of symmetry
formula, we get
$$$xx​=−2ab​=−2(−2)(−12)​​$$$
$$$x=−3​$$$


Using the method of completing the square, we have
$$$f(x)​=−2x2−12x−10=−2[x2+6x]−10=−2[(x+3)2−9]−10=−2(x+3)2+8​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are  $(−3,8)​$


We have
$$$transformation 1:transformation 2:​reflection in the y-axistranslation of two units upwards​$$$
If we apply the transformations $1$ and $2$ to P, we find


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b2539ad3-5cb1-47b4-82fb-0f17c7d9b8b2/images/5463dadf-bc47-4d8c-a965-e2b73e47474d/e1df7f8211664f00389891c42cbdf0bb7d3cdd9a.svg)


Hence the coordinates of Q are
$(2,8)​$
